results.title: Maddingley
results.creator_credit: APM Productions, Atlas Associates and Cambridge Films
results.brief_description: A documentary film showing the brown coal mining process at Maddingley in Bacchus Marsh, Victoria, and then goes on to show how the coal is used for the production of paper at the Australian Paper Mills plant. Also includes scenes of the workers and their families of Bacchus Marsh at play.
results.creator_credit_for_label: APM Productions, Atlas Associates and Cambridge Films

results.title: Madarrpa funeral at Gurka'wuy
results.brief_description: In the small Aboriginal community of Gurka’wuy, 170 kms. south of Yirrkala, a baby dies. Subtitled “a way of coping with death in north-east Arnhem Land through ties of clan, religion and land”, this film, photographed by Dean Semler, depicts the three day long preparations for the funeral, and the funeral itself. The ceremonies, dances, songs and paintings are described in detail, as the child is symbolically returned to its clan lands further south.

results.title: Mad Max II (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Byron Kennedy, Kennedy Miller Productions and George Miller
results.brief_description: Mad Max helps a small community defend itself against gangs desperate for fuel. Set in a post WW3 world where gasoline is the only hard currency. Stars Mel Gibson and Bruce Spence.

results.title: Mad love: three films by Evgenii Bauer
results.brief_description: Three short silent films by Soviet director Evegnii Bauer. “Twilight of a woman’s soul” Vera, a wealthy lady of society who distributes alms to the poor is raped by a lascivious working class brute; traumatised, she kills him. Shortly after she becomes engaged to a charming and urbane Prince, who, appalled by her confession, spurns her, only to regret his impetuousness. “After death” Andrei, a young man living in seclusion, is obsessed with death. He attends a lavish garden party where he meets a beguiling actress. Andrei rejects her declaration of love, and following her suicide, laments his actions and is haunted by her ghost. “The Dying swan” A painter, obsessed with capturing death in his work, becomes enraptured with the talents of a mute ballerina whose most famed work is ‘The Dying swan’. When the dancer becomes enlivened by love, the artist determines that she will remain the essence of death. In these expressionistic works, Bauer explores the themes of obsession, death, desire, suicide, tragic love and the artistic temperament depicting a reality permeated by dreams, ghosts and visions. With musical score, Russian intertitles and English subtitles.

results.title: Mad double!
results.creator_credit: Thirtieth Cemalux and Home Entertainment Holdings
results.brief_description: Featuring the slapstick madness of two of Hollywood’s most famous comedy duos, Abbott and Costello and Laurel and Hardy, this compilation video also includes excerpts from two Abbott and Costello films and their classic comedy sketch “Who’s on first?” and two Laurel and Hardy films, “Tit for tat” and “Another fine mess”.

results.title: Macrame
results.brief_description: This film gives an introduction to the craft of macrame, showing the basic knots and how they can be used to create chains, twists and spirals to give a variegated effect. The film also introduces the craft.

results.title: Mackintosh 1868-1928
results.creator_credit: International Film Associates, Films of Scotland, Scottish Arts Council and Murray Grigor
results.brief_description: Born in Glasgow in 1868, Charles Rennie Mackintosh was one of the first pioneers of modern design and architecture. Combining Scottish, Japanese and English influences, he created styles and designs which were not just ahead of his time but ones which stand the test of time. His contribution to the world of art and design is now recognised internationally. This documentary traces his career from his early paintings to his architectural commissions and the final landscapes. Mackintosh’s work was a complete reversal of contemporary design, he made decoration intrinsic to the whole.
